item.title: German Exports Fall More Than Expected as US Shipments Sink
item.description: German exports sank more than anticipated in May as the value of shipments to the US plunged to their lowest level in more than three years amid President Donald Trump’s tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for export at the Port of Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Indonesia’s Chief Negotiator Heads to US to Discuss Tariffs
item.description: Indonesia will immediately resume tariff negotiations with the US to lower the 32% tariff that President Donald Trump threatens to impose starting August, while working to diversify its trade with other export markets.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Airlangga Hartarto Photographer: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Getty Images

item.title: UK Faces £22 Billion Hit as Pension Gilt-Buying Wanes, OBR Says
item.description: Britain is at risk of a £22 billion ($29.9 billion) surge in the government’s debt-interest bill as pension schemes buy fewer gilts, making the country heavily dependent on foreign investors to snap up public debt.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

item.title: US Small-Business Optimism Fell Slightly Before Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses fell slightly in June as owners continued to worry about taxes ahead of a major legislative win for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Georgina Boos

media:content.media:description: A hardware store in San Francisco.

item.title: Milei’s Secret Weapon Is an Anti-Woke Devotee of ‘The West Wing’
item.description: Santiago Caputo is upending Argentine politics amid rumored tension with the libertarian president’s sister ahead of a crucial midterm vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Tattoos peek through Santiago Caputo’s sleeves outside the Casa Rosada in Buenos Aires.

item.title: EU Increasingly Trades With Autocrats and Dictators, ECB Research Shows
item.description: Europe’s trading partners have become less democratic over the past quarter century, contrary to a commitment by governments to pay attention to political, human and social rights, according to research published by the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Trade with China accounts for about one-fifth of all imports into the EU.

item.title: US Clouds Malaysia Rate Path With Surprise 25% Tariff Threat
item.description: The surprise US decision to raise its threatened tariff on Malaysia to 25% means trade will almost certainly dominate the Southeast Asian nation’s interest rate decision on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: US Tariff Delay Might Soften Christmas Impact, UBS’ Donovan Says
item.description: Donald Trump’s delay of tariff increases until Aug. 1 may have just softened the price impact for Christmas by pushing it into 2026, according to UBS Group AG Chief Economist Paul Donovan.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Toys imported from abroad line the shelves of a toy store in Miami Beach.

item.title: Japan Gets 25% Tariffs With Room to Seek Deal Past Election
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba called the announcement of slightly higher US tariffs “truly regrettable” while he vowed to continue to protect his nation’s interests in the extended trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Naira Decouples from Oil as Confidence in Nigerian Reforms Grows
item.description: Nigeria’s currency appears to be decoupling from the price of oil, the nation’s main foreign-exchange earner.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Osae-Brown, Emele Onu

item.title: Russia Locks Up Population Data With War in Ukraine in Its Fourth Year
item.description: Unlocking a full picture of Russia’s demographic situation is becoming increasingly hard after the state stopped publishing monthly statistics amid the Kremlin’s war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

item.title: South Korea Vows to Review Rules Following Trump’s Tariff Letter
item.description: South Korea said it will review regulations flagged by the US while pressing for an easing of sectoral tariffs after President Donald Trump sent a letter with a new August deadline for imposing 25% across-the-board levies.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Container ships are docked as shipping containers sit in the Busan Port Terminal (BPT) in this aerial photograph taken in Busan, South Korea, on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2020. South Korea’s central bank left its key interest rate unchanged on Wednesday amid signs that a resurgence of the coronavirus at home is waning and exports and inflation are picking up.

item.title: Australia's Central Bank Surprises Market by Holding Key Rate
item.description: Australia’s central bank surprised investors and economists by keeping interest rates unchanged on Tuesday and signaled a wait-and-see approach on policy as US tariff plans stoke uncertainty across the world.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Thailand Confident of Lowering US Tariff With Trade Offers
item.description: Thailand remains optimistic about securing a lower tariff rate than the 36% levy announced by President Donald Trump, based on its offer to reduce import tax on most US goods to zero, Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

item.title: Hungary Inflation Accelerates as Expected on Food, Energy Costs
item.description: Hungary’s inflation accelerated in June, with a jump in the cost of food, household energy and services despite the government’s regulatory curbs.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: A butchers stall at the Great Market Hall food market in Budapest.

item.title: South Africa’s Ramaphosa Sees Scope to Lower US Tariff in Talks
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said there’s the prospect that the US may lower a planned 30% tariff on goods in ongoing talks with Washington, as he challenged its calculation of the new levy.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

item.title: Asian Economies in Rush to Cut Tariff Deals as US Deadline Moves
item.description: Asian countries including Japan and South Korea said they’ll keep pushing for a better deal for their exports to the US after President Donald Trump shifted his tariff deadline to Aug. 1 and tweaked the rates he’s set for many economies.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Soo-Hyang Choi

item.title: Will Trade War Make South India the Next Manufacturing Hub?
item.description: States like Tamil Nadu are dangling tax breaks and fast-tracking infrastructure, helping the country shake off its reputation as a difficult place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Dan Strumpf, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Putting the finishing touches on Ather scooters at the company’s factory in Hosur, Tamil Nadu.

item.title: Romania to Hold Rates as Tax Changes Hit Prices: Decision Guide
item.description: Romania’s central bank is likely to leave borrowing costs unchanged as the government’s recently announced tax hikes are expected to trigger a new spike in inflation over the coming months.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: The Romanian central bank in Bucharest, Romania.

item.title: Malaysia Commits to Trade Talks After Higher US Tariff Threat
item.description: Malaysia said it will continue to engage with the US after President Donald Trump threatened to impose a steeper tariff rate unless the Southeast Asian nation reaches an agreement with his administration.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: China Shuns Costly LNG Imports Even as Summer Power Demand Rises
item.description: Sweltering temperatures are pushing up appetite for electricity in China — just not yet enough to revive the country’s spot purchases of costly liquefied natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Kathy Chen

item.title: Affordable Homes in India Dwindle to 7-Year Low, Report Shows
item.description: India’s supply of houses costing less than 5 million rupees ($58,553) fell to their lowest since 2018, a Knight Frank report found, signaling that the trend of developers pivoting away from this segment continues.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Ajith

item.title: Australia Business Conditions and Confidence Jump Ahead of RBA Decision
item.description: Australian business conditions jumped as sales, profitability and employment surged while confidence also climbed, suggesting a recovery in the corporate sector may be unfolding in line with the Reserve Bank’s easing cycle.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Japan’s Early June Exports Rise Slightly Ahead of Higher Tariffs
item.description: Japan’s exports edged up in the first 20 days of June ahead of the Trump administration’s scheduled imposition of higher tariffs as US policy continues to impact trade flows.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Colombian Inflation Slows More Than Forecast to 4.82%
item.description: Colombia’s inflation rate dropped to its lowest level in nearly four years, potentially bolstering the case of the central bank minority who voted for an interest rate cut last month.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

item.title: Fund Managers Bet on Bank, Consumer Stocks After India Rate Cuts
item.description: Money managers are betting Indian banking and consumption stocks have further to run this year, benefiting from the central bank’s aggressive policy rate cuts to lift economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Vishnoi

item.title: Ghana Unlocks $367 Million Disbursement From IMF After Review
item.description: Ghana will receive another $367 million disbursement from the International Monetary Fund after passing the fourth review of its $3 billion program with the Washington-based lender.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

item.title: Carney’s Cabinet Searches for Spending Cuts as Defense Bill Grows
item.description: Canada’s finance minister has asked members of cabinet to find billions of dollars in spending cuts as the government looks for ways to pay for a larger defense budget and capital projects.
